abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Emergency Drought Recovery
            Project(EDRP). The EDRP had two main objectives: (a) to
            alleviate the impact of the current drought on the poor and
            vulnerable in the most affected areas of Darfur, Kordofan,
            Khartoum and the Eastern State, and the towns of Juba, Wau
            and Malakal in the south; and (b) to initiate an action plan
            to improve longer term food security. The preparation of the
            project was coordinated at all stages with the International
            Monetary Fund (IMF) and major multilaterals. All parties to
            the project agreed that it was necessary to provide a
            package of relief services, agricultural inputs, and medical
            supplies to target those most affected, and to use existing
            Government agencies and organizations which were already
            significantly involved in relief activities (e.g.United
            Nations Children's fund (UNICEF) in the project's
            implementation. The key lessons learned are: (i) production
            shortfalls need not necessarily result in famine. The most
            negative effects of drought may be avoided through early
            awareness, adequate preparedness and response; (ii) an
            emergency situation calls for massive and rapid response,
            therefore, such an intervention must take advantage of
            previously available infrastructure and institutions; (iii)
            targeting scarce resources is critical for ensuring maximum
            impact of an emergency intervention. Successful targeting
            depends on a good understanding of the causes and process of
            the emergency, so the most vulnerable can be identified and
            mechanisms created to reach them; (iv) the successful
            provision of relief services and inputs to promote immediate
            recovery must be conducted in a timely fashion. Intervention
            plans must take into account procurement and logistic delays
            and accordingly ensure that planning is realistic; (v) the
            success of costrecovery systems depends in-part on the
            priorities set by end users and their disposable income. The
            priority accorded to water in rural areas indicates that
            water service development may be feasible on a more
            commercial basis in some areas; (vi) cost-recovery systems
            demand strong service delivery systems, good management and
            minimum levels of community purchasing power. If some of
            these conditions are not met,development of cost-recovery
            systems may be premature or require concurrent development
            of parallelsystems; (vii) national TA programs can be
            successful through using local skilled labour, consolidating
            local knowledge, and promoting greater ownership and use of
            results; and (viii) in an acute drought/famine situation,
            the distinction between immediate requirement for food aid
            and replenishment of seed supplies must be recognized. The
            loss of some seed imports through home consumption is
            inevitable given the critical shortage of food until the
            next harvest.
